Literature Review: Maternal mortality in the United States presents a complex public health challenge, characterized by rates that significantly exceed those of other high-income countries. This literature review explores the trends, disparities, and potential strategies for prevention of maternal mortality in the U.S., with a focus on the evolving causes of pregnancy-related deaths and the role of preconception and postpartum care in mitigating risks. Recent studies have highlighted a concerning trend in the U.S., where maternal mortality rates have not only remained high but have also shown an increase over the past decades. Creanga et al. (2017) documented that the maternal mortality ratio in the U.S. increased from 7.2 deaths per 100,000 live births in 1987 to 17.3 deaths per 100,000 live births in 2013, underscoring the urgency of addressing this issue. A significant factor contributing to this trend is the shift in the underlying causes of maternal deaths. While hemorrhage and hypertensive disorders of pregnancy were historically the leading causes, recent data indicate a relative increase in deaths due to cardiovascular conditions and preexisting medical conditions. This shift necessitates a reevaluation of current maternal health care strategies to better address these emerging risks. Disparities in maternal mortality rates by race/ethnicity, geography, and socioeconomic status further complicate the U.S. maternal health landscape. African American women, for instance, experience maternal mortality rates three to four times higher than those of white women, a disparity that persists across income and education levels. Geographic disparities are also evident, with women in rural areas facing higher risks of maternal death compared to their urban counterparts. These disparities highlight the need for targeted interventions that address the social determinants of health and improve access to quality maternal health care for all women. Preconception health and preconception counseling have emerged as critical components of strategies aimed at reducing maternal mortality. By identifying and managing preexisting conditions and risk factors before pregnancy, health care providers can mitigate the risks of adverse pregnancy outcomes. Studies have shown that interventions focusing on preconception health, such as the management of chronic conditions and the promotion of healthy lifestyles, can significantly reduce the risk of maternal death. Similarly, ensuring continuity of care, including primary care visits within the first year postpartum, is essential for identifying and addressing health issues that may arise after delivery. In conclusion, addressing the high rates of maternal mortality in the United States requires a multifaceted approach that includes improving preconception and postpartum care, addressing disparities in maternal health outcomes, and adapting maternal health care strategies to the changing landscape of pregnancy-related deaths. By focusing on these areas, it is possible to make significant strides in reducing maternal mortality and improving the health and well-being of women across the nation.
